channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: U.S. elections face more threats from foreign actors and artificial intelligence
item.description: "Russia remains the most active foreign threat to our elections," said Director of National Intelligence Avril Haines, noting that new AI technologies make influence operations easier to pull off.
item.content:encoded:
"Russia remains the most active foreign threat to our elections," said Director of National Intelligence Avril Haines, noting that new AI technologies make influence operations easier to pull off.

(Image credit: Win McNamee)
item.dc:creator: Shannon Bond

item.title: Supreme Court upholds Louisiana redistricting plan
item.description: A federal district court ruled that the new map drawn by the state legislature violated the Voting Rights Act by diluting the Black vote. A group of conservatives challenged the legislature's map.
item.content:encoded:
A federal district court ruled that the new map drawn by the state legislature violated the Voting Rights Act by diluting the Black vote. A group of conservatives challenged the legislature's map.

(Image credit: Chip Somodevilla)
item.dc:creator: Nina Totenberg

item.title: France imposes a state of emergency in New Caledonia as unrest continues
item.description: People in the French Pacific territory of New Caledonia are protesting a reform that would give voting rights to an increasing number of non-Indigenous residents of the archipelago.
item.content:encoded:
People in the French Pacific territory of New Caledonia are protesting a reform that would give voting rights to an increasing number of non-Indigenous residents of the archipelago.

(Image credit: Delphine Mayeur)
item.dc:creator: Eleanor Beardsley

item.title: How a migrant aid group got caught up in a right-wing social media thread
item.description:
A conservative group posted a social media thread showing flyers in a border encampment in Mexico urging migrants to vote for Joe Biden. Now, the woman caught up in it, speaks to NPR.

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org.
item.content:encoded:
A conservative group posted a social media thread showing flyers in a border encampment in Mexico urging migrants to vote for Joe Biden. Now, the woman caught up in it, speaks to NPR.

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org.

item.title: Latinas are succeeding, but feel pressured to playing traditional roles for women
item.description: Report from the Pew Research Center says Hispanic women in general continue to face pressure to play traditional roles, despite advances in educational attainment and entrepreneurship
item.content:encoded:
Report from the Pew Research Center says Hispanic women in general continue to face pressure to play traditional roles, despite advances in educational attainment and entrepreneurship

(Image credit: Stella Chavez)
item.dc:creator: Stella Chavez

item.title: A Visit to a "Marriage Market" in China
item.description: China, the country that once feared overpopulation, is now experiencing a falling birthrate. The government is encouraging its citizens to have children. We visit a "marriage market" where hopeful young people are looking for a match.
item.content:encoded: China, the country that once feared overpopulation, is now experiencing a falling birthrate. The government is encouraging its citizens to have children. We visit a "marriage market" where hopeful young people are looking for a match.
item.dc:creator: Steve Inskeep

item.title: A bipartisan group of senators unveils a plan to tackle artificial intelligence
item.description: This comes after a yearlong listening tour by a bipartisan working group in the Senate.
item.content:encoded:
This comes after a yearlong listening tour by a bipartisan working group in the Senate.

(Image credit: Allison Bailey)
item.dc:creator: Barbara Sprunt

item.title: Gaza will be 'one big displacement camp' for the foreseeable future, journalist says
item.description: The Economist Middle East correspondent Gregg Carlstrom explains why some Arab leaders hate Hamas, fear Iran and have some sympathy for Israel â although not for how Israel is waging the war.
item.content:encoded: The Economist Middle East correspondent Gregg Carlstrom explains why some Arab leaders hate Hamas, fear Iran and have some sympathy for Israel â although not for how Israel is waging the war.
item.dc:creator: Terry Gross

item.title: Egg and milk prices fall, fueling hope for interest rate cuts
item.description: Inflation eased last month, according to a report Wednesday from the Labor Department, which means people feeling stretched by high prices and high borrowing costs could feel a little relief soon.
item.content:encoded:
Inflation eased last month, according to a report Wednesday from the Labor Department, which means people feeling stretched by high prices and high borrowing costs could feel a little relief soon.

(Image credit: Justin Sullivan)
item.dc:creator: Scott Horsley

item.title: Why the U.N. revised the numbers of women and children killed in Gaza
item.description: Here's a closer look at the United Nations' breakdown of casualties. The overall total of more than 35,000 Palestinians killed since Oct. 7, based on Gaza Health Ministry figures, has not declined.
item.content:encoded: Here's a closer look at the United Nations' breakdown of casualties. The overall total of more than 35,000 Palestinians killed since Oct. 7, based on Gaza Health Ministry figures, has not declined.
item.dc:creator: Aya Batrawy
